One of the most astounding results of the election
campaign is the realization of the waning power of
the press. Eighty per cent of the press of the nation
was solidly aligned against President Roosevelt. It is
evident that the day when the American newspaper
can swing an election is past. The ugly head of American journalism has shouted more charges and counter
charges, and has provided more mud-slinging, than in
any election since the Cleveland-Blaine campaign of
1884. Yet Roosevelt, with the greatest newspapers
against him, won overwhelmingly.
This one has been a campaign of labels—and except
for that provided by the small radical political groups,
all the labels have come from the Republican camps.
Every word synonymous with "un-American" and "socialistic" has been applied to Mr. Roosevelt and his
advisors. The American press has provided more editorial abuse than ever before in its history. It is unfortunate that American journalism, with all its potential
influence and possibilities of educating the public, should
stoop to smoke screen and vilification to serve its own
ends.
Probably the greatest factor in the waning power of
the press is the rapidly increasing use of the radio. All
of the important addresses of the presidential candidates were carried throughout the country by nationwide hook-ups. Gone is the possibility of making sectional appeals through the country. A serious nominee can no longer hope to convince a farmer gathering
in the middle West that he intends to provide an
expensive farm program, if in New York he promises
an urban and industrialist audience that he will balance the budget. With the radio flashing every word
over the nation It is impossible to make conflicting
promises in different sections of the country.

For one of Baltimore's brightest
bright spots, you certainly shouldn't
miss going to the Lord Baltimore
Bubble Room—a place bubbling over
with sweet rhythm, pleasant atmosphere, and excellent food and drinks.
This past week-end we bumped into
(literally speaking, too) a goodry portion of Hopkins and Gouch,er enjoying the melodies of Johnny Johnson
ana his Taut yeast Jesters.
Ex-ODK President T. Bayard Williams was dreamy - eyed with his
blonde date . . . Marty Levine and
Jeanne Miller were rehearsing Barnstormer lines (or what lines were
they, Marty) over glasses of gigglewater . . . Henry Kramer, Dave Caplan, and Seymour Sachs were also
observed with eye-filling examples of
the weaker sex.

LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
To the Editor:
The daily activities of students,
comprised for the most part of lectures and study, quizzes—passed or
flunked, dates--good and bad, are all
very important.
But there exist larger problems
which directly and indirectly affect
the student. As much as tne student
would like to rule out the questions
of searching for a job and of being
drafted into a coming war, he is unable to do so. These problems are
real, and more and more students are
beginning to consider them seriously.
The members of the Johns Hopkins
Chapter of the Young Communist
League are students who have examined the present situation and found
it sadly deficient in its ability to give
students a secure an,. worthwmle
existence. We desire to improve the
Young Communist League because we
believe its program is an effective
one in attaining those goals.
1. The Young Communist League
stands for a vigorous and determined
fight against war and fascism. A
united student body together with the
liberal and progressive forces on and
off the campus is the main bulwark
against these turn menaces.
2. We are for the maintenance and
extension of civil liberties in general
and freedom of speech and thought on
the campus in particular.
3. We are for adequate student aid
and demand the extension of the
N.Y.A. to all who need it until the more
desirable Youth Act has been passed
by Congress.
4. We are for the equality of all, regardless of race, color or religion.
5. We stand for socialism--for the
change of capitalist society to one
based on production for use and not
for profit.
We aim not only to educate students
and all youth into the principles of
socialism but also to fight for the day
to day needs of students.
We ask you to think this over honestly and fairly. Our interests are the
best ones of American Youth—for
"Life, Liberty, and the Pursuit of
Happiness."
With the coming into the open of a
group of play-boy fascists, it is of
great importance that our fellow students know and understand our program.
We stand for those changes which
must occur if society is to progress.
This is Americanism.
We welcome anyone who wishes to
become one of us, and any questions
which might arise.
The Johns Hopkins Chapter,
Young Communist League
501 B N. Eutaw Place

IN MEMORIAM
To the Editor of the NEws-LETTEA
Sir:
This is to inform you and others tha
the Americanistic League has been
disbanded by order of the President
G. G. Duce.
Please publish statements to this
effect. After today, it does not exist
in any form.
I should like all members to destroy
or return their membership cards to
me at once. (P. 0. 65).
Action from now on against Corn
munism will be only individual. Al
though I have given up the League
I shall continue my individual work
against them. Any statements made
by anyone, speaking as a member of
the Ex-Americanistic League vs.
Communism, are only individual opinions, and I will assume no responsibility for any statements I do not make
myself, or for any actions except my
own.
Yours truly,
Gordon G. Duce

One of the most astounding results of the election
campaign is the realization of the waning power of
the press. Eighty per cent of the press of the nation
was solidly aligned against President Roosevelt. It is
evident that the day when the American newspaper
can swing an election is past. The ugly head of American journalism has shouted more charges and counter
charges, and has provided more mud-slinging, than in
any election since the Cleveland-Blaine campaign of
1884. Yet Roosevelt, with the greatest newspapers
against him, won overwhelmingly.
This one has been a campaign of labels—and except
for that provided by the small radical political groups,
all the labels have come from the Republican camps.
Every word synonymous with "un-American" and "socialistic" has been applied to Mr. Roosevelt and his
advisors. The American press has provided more editorial abuse than ever before in its history. It is unfortunate that American journalism, with all its potential
influence and possibilities of educating the public, should
stoop to smoke screen and vilification to serve its own
ends.
Probably the greatest factor in the waning power of
the press is the rapidly increasing use of the radio. All
of the important addresses of the presidential candidates were carried throughout the country by nationwide hook-ups. Gone is the possibility of making sectional appeals through the country. A serious nominee can no longer hope to convince a farmer gathering
in the middle West that he intends to provide an
expensive farm program, if in New York he promises
an urban and industrialist audience that he will balance the budget. With the radio flashing every word
over the nation It is impossible to make conflicting
promises in different sections of the country.

LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
To the Editor:
The daily activities of students,
comprised for the most part of lectures and study, quizzes—passed or
flunked, dates--good and bad, are all
very important.
But there exist larger problems
which directly and indirectly affect
the student. As much as tne student
would like to rule out the questions
of searching for a job and of being
drafted into a coming war, he is unable to do so. These problems are
real, and more and more students are
beginning to consider them seriously.
The members of the Johns Hopkins
Chapter of the Young Communist
League are students who have examined the present situation and found
it sadly deficient in its ability to give
students a secure an,. worthwmle
existence. We desire to improve the
Young Communist League because we
believe its program is an effective
one in attaining those goals.
1. The Young Communist League
stands for a vigorous and determined
fight against war and fascism. A
united student body together with the
liberal and progressive forces on and
off the campus is the main bulwark
against these turn menaces.
2. We are for the maintenance and
extension of civil liberties in general
and freedom of speech and thought on
the campus in particular.
3. We are for adequate student aid
and demand the extension of the
N.Y.A. to all who need it until the more
desirable Youth Act has been passed
by Congress.
4. We are for the equality of all, regardless of race, color or religion.
5. We stand for socialism--for the
change of capitalist society to one
based on production for use and not
for profit.
We aim not only to educate students
and all youth into the principles of
socialism but also to fight for the day
to day needs of students.
We ask you to think this over honestly and fairly. Our interests are the
best ones of American Youth—for
"Life, Liberty, and the Pursuit of
Happiness."
With the coming into the open of a
group of play-boy fascists, it is of
great importance that our fellow students know and understand our program.
We stand for those changes which
must occur if society is to progress.
This is Americanism.
We welcome anyone who wishes to
become one of us, and any questions
which might arise.
The Johns Hopkins Chapter,
Young Communist League
501 B N. Eutaw Place

IN MEMORIAM
To the Editor of the NEws-LETTEA
Sir:
This is to inform you and others tha
the Americanistic League has been
disbanded by order of the President
G. G. Duce.
Please publish statements to this
effect. After today, it does not exist
in any form.
I should like all members to destroy
or return their membership cards to
me at once. (P. 0. 65).
Action from now on against Corn
munism will be only individual. Al
though I have given up the League
I shall continue my individual work
against them. Any statements made
by anyone, speaking as a member of
the Ex-Americanistic League vs.
Communism, are only individual opinions, and I will assume no responsibility for any statements I do not make
myself, or for any actions except my
own.
Yours truly,
Gordon G. Duce
